section.title: Introduction
section.para: mod_auth_feide is an authentication module for Apache built on top of the libfeide library (distributed with this document). It works in a simple fashion, redirecting users to a webpage at login.feide.no where the users can authenticate themselves with username and password before being redirected back to the resource they requested before authentication.
This document contains instruction on how to install the software and how to configure it with Apache.

listitem.para: An OS that supports anonymous shared memory
Edit Makefile to suit your system. You should only need to change the variable that say where APXS is.

section.title: FeideVariable
section.para: FEIDE works by redirecting users to the authentication service, and getting redirected back. auth_feide knows that the user has been authenticated when a GET variable is added to the URL that the user requests. The webserver can decide the name of this variable, nad it is set with FeideVariable.

section.title: FeideUrl
section.para: The URL to the authentication service.

section.title: FeideServerUser
section.para: The authentication service uses HTTP Basic Authentication to protect access to it from different clients (client like auth_feide). This sets the authentication username.
You will probably have been given a value to put here by the authentication service administrators.

section.title: FeideServerPassword
section.para: The HTTP Basic Authentication password to go with FeideServerUser.

section.title: FeideDomain
section.para: To seperate between different resources that need authentication you set different FeideDomains for the resources.

section.title: FeideRequire
section.para: This controls access for "authenticated" users. When they are being redirected from the authentication service to the resource they requested, auth_feide will query the authentication service for attributes that contain information about the user. Then they will be matched against the different FeideRequire statements. FeideRequire takes multiple arguments, where the first argument is alwats the name of the attribute followed by a list of values. There is an implicit OR between the different vlaues in the list. If you want to have an AND between the different values, you would have to put them on seperate lines (yes, multiple FeideRequire statements are allowed).

section.title: FeideCacheSize
section.para: The auth_feide module will cache authentications locally so that the user won't have to be redirected to the authentication service for each request. FeideCacheSize says how many authentications the server will cache. Note that unlike the above configuration directives this is for the whole server.

section.title: FeideCacheAge
section.para: How long the cached authentications be valid. This is also a global configuration directive. The value is given in seconds.
